Field Label: Was a behavior modifying strategy recommended?
Which behavior modifying strategy was recommended?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Systematic Desensitization (Systematic desensitization is a behavioral technique that involves exposing a dog gradually and systematically to an anxiety-producing person, other animal, object or event beginning with the stimulus at a very low level (e.g., the subject to be desensitized is presented with the fear inducing stimulus at a reduced intensity by arranging for it to be farther away or with fear of sounds substantially reducing the volume and then gradually increasing exposure to the stimulus until it is tolerated at full intensity). | 2, Counterconditioning (teaching an opposite behavioral response to a once fear-inducing stimulus, e.g., a stranger's approach initially = fear; that response is changed so that the stranger's approach always predicts a valuable reward, i.e. stranger = good stuff) | 3, A combination of systematic desensitization and counterconditioning | 4, Leadership program (a.k.a. Learn to earn, Nothing in life is free, No free lunch, Working for a living, "Say please.") | 5, Medication - A veterinarian prescribed medication for use during behavior modification supervised by a trainer or behavior specialist | 6, Medication - A veterinarian prescribed medication as a standalone treatment (e.g., without the addition of training/behavior modification)

Field Label:
Which of the following techniques were used:
<font size=1 color="blue">Check all that apply</font>
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Mental stimulation and enrichment (e.g., nose work, puzzle toys) | 2, Relaxation protocol | 3, Increase in physical exercise | 4, Habituation (gradually increasing exposure to a lower level of an aversive stimulus, e.g., placing a nail clipper somewhere the dog can see it and over time moving it closer to the dog) | 5, Flooding (inescapable exposure to a full strength aversive, e.g., throwing you into a swimming pool full of snakes and keeping you there until you stop screaming) | 6, Response blocking (physically preventing a dog from performing an undesired behavior, e.g. lunging, until the behavior stops) | 7, Management (preventing exposure to a stimulus, e.g., putting the dog in another room when company arrives to prevent jumping) | 8, Reduction or elimination of other stressors or distractions while training | 9, Marker or clicker training | 10, Play | 11, Participation in dog sports (e.g., agility, obedience, flyball) | 12, Ignoring bad behavior (reinforcement is removed, leading to extinction of the behavior) | 13, Training alternatives to problem behavior (e.g., teach and reinforce sit and ignore jumping) | 14, Short but frequent sessions v. longer, infrequent sessions | 15, Group classes | 16, Private sessions | 17, Change in diet | 18, Improve communication between dog and owner (understanding canine body language, e.g., stress, fear, aggression) | 19, Other
